title: Headward erosion
text:
Headward erosion is <a href="erosion">erosion</a> at the origin of a <a href="channel%20%28geography%29">stream channel</a>, which causes the origin to move back away from the direction of the stream flow, lengthening the stream channel. It can also refer to widening of a <a href="canyon">canyon</a> by erosion along its very top edge, when sheets of water first enter the canyon from a more roughly planar surface above it, such as at <a href="Canyonlands%20National%20Park">Canyonlands National Park</a> in <a href="Utah">Utah</a>. When sheets of water on a roughly planar surface first enter a depression in it, this erodes the top edge of the depression. The stream is forced to grow longer at the very top of the stream, which moves its origin back, or causes the canyon formed by the stream to grow wider as the process repeats. Widening of the canyon by erosion inside the canyon, below the canyon side top edge, or origin or the stream, such as erosion caused by the streamflow inside it, is not called headwall erosion.
Headward erosion is a <a href="fluvial">fluvial</a> process of <a href="erosion">erosion</a> that lengthens a <a href="stream">stream</a>, a <a href="valley">valley</a> or a <a href="gully">gully</a> at its <a href="source%20%28river%20or%20stream%29">head</a> and also enlarges its <a href="drainage%20basin">drainage basin</a>. The stream erodes away at the rock and soil at its headwaters in the opposite direction that it flows. Once a stream has begun to cut back, the erosion is sped up by the steep gradient the water is flowing down. As water erodes a path from its headwaters to its mouth at a standing body of water, it tries to cut an ever-shallower path. This leads to increased erosion at the steepest parts, which is headward erosion. If this continues long enough, it can cause a stream to break through into a neighboring <a href="drainage%20basin">watershed</a> and <a href="stream%20capture">capture</a> drainage that previously flowed to another stream.
For example, headward erosion by the <a href="Shenandoah%20River">Shenandoah River</a>, a <a href="tributary">tributary</a> of the <a href="Potomac%20River">Potomac River</a> in the U.S. state of <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a>, permitted the Shenandoah to capture successively the original upstream segments of <a href="Beaverdam%20Creek%20%28Virginia%29">Beaverdam Creek</a>, <a href="Gap%20Run">Gap Run</a> and <a href="Goose%20Creek%20%28Potomac%20River%29">Goose Creek</a>, three smaller tributaries of the Potomac. As each capture added to the Shenandoah's <a href="effluent">effluent</a>, or discharge, it accelerated the process of headward erosion until the Shenandoah captured all drainage to the Potomac west of the <a href="Blue%20Ridge%20Mountains">Blue Ridge Mountains</a>.
Stream types created by headward erosion.
Three kinds of streams are formed by headward erosion: "insequent streams", "subsequent streams", and "obsequent and resequent streams" ("See <a href="Fluvial%20landforms%20of%20streams">Fluvial landforms of streams</a>".) 
Insequent streams form by random headward erosion, usually from sheetflow of water over the landform surface. The water collects in channels where the velocity and erosional power increase, cutting into and extending the heads of gullies. 
Subsequent streams form by selective headward erosion by cutting away at less resistive rocks in the terrain. 
Obsequent and resequent streams form after time in an area of insequent or subsequent streams. Obsequent streams are insequent streams that now flow in an opposite direction of the original drainage pattern. Resequent streams are subsequent streams that have also changed direction from their original drainage patterns.
Drainage patterns created by headward erosion.
Headward erosion creates three major kinds of drainage patterns: "<a href="Drainage_system_%28geomorphology%29">dendritic</a> patterns", "<a href="Drainage_system_%28geomorphology%29">trellis</a> patterns", and "rectangular and angular patterns". 
<br>
Four minor kinds of drainage patterns also can be created: "<a href="wikt%3Aradial">radial</a> patterns", "<a href="wikt%3Aannular">annular</a> patterns", <br>
"<a href="Centripetal%20force">centripetal</a> patterns" and "<a href="wikt%3Aparallel">parallel</a> patterns".
